text:
Swift for Tensorflow shuts down
<https://github.com/tensorflow/swift|https://github.com/tensorflow/swift>

elements.text: Swift for Tensorflow shuts down
https://github.com/tensorflow/swift

text: What are the implications of this for tensorflow? I was under the (probably mistaken) impression that this was the next big thing for tensorflow.

elements.text: What are the implications of this for tensorflow? I was under the (probably mistaken) impression that this was the next big thing for tensorflow.

text: There's a thread about this in this same channel, half a screen up :smile:

elements.text: There's a thread about this in this same channel, half a screen up

text: Whoops sorry!

elements.text: Whoops sorry!

text: I browsed through that thread, and I don’t feel any more knowledgeable.

elements.text: I browsed through that thread, and I don’t feel any more knowledgeable.

text: I see nothing about the project being shut down?

elements.text: I see nothing about the project being shut down?

text: The intro to the readme says it's been archived

elements.text: The intro to the readme says it's been archived

text: It seems to be "put on hold" for a while.

elements.text: It seems to be "put on hold" for a while.

text: wonder what that even means... I never tried swift

elements.text: wonder what that even means... I never tried swift

text: It means Google is being Google and not following through on a project. This is hardly abnormal for them

elements.text: It means Google is being Google and not following through on a project. This is hardly abnormal for them

text: Knowing google, it was probably inevitable as soon as it didn’t take over to become the default way of using TF, and certainly inevitable once Chris Lattner left

elements.text: Knowing google, it was probably inevitable as soon as it didn’t take over to become the default way of using TF, and certainly inevitable once Chris Lattner left

text: It always blew my mind when I’d hear people get excited about Swift4Tensorflow and claim to already be in the process of switching their code over

elements.text: It always blew my mind when I’d hear people get excited about Swift4Tensorflow and claim to already be in the process of switching their code over

text: Oof, yeah

elements.text: Oof, yeah

text: oh wow that guy wrote a boatload of llvm... that's next level stuff...

elements.text: oh wow that guy wrote a boatload of llvm... that's next level stuff...

text: And a bunch of Swift, “not coincidentally” :p

elements.text: And a bunch of Swift, “not coincidentally” :p

text: I hear a lot about swift, but, then at the same time I don't... I think the GC just throws people off, but despite that it does seem fast for a GC language

elements.text: I hear a lot about swift, but, then at the same time I don't... I think the GC just throws people off, but despite that it does seem fast for a GC language

text: It's the defacto language for iOS development, so it has a very big community, just not a scientific community.

elements.text: It's the defacto language for iOS development, so it has a very big community, just not a scientific community.

text: GCs don't make languages slow. Hitting a GC can make certain code slow.

elements.text: GCs don't make languages slow. Hitting a GC can make certain code slow.

text: I look at Swift as yet another contender in the overcrowded family of languages trying to be a "Better C++:tm:"

elements.text: I look at Swift as yet another contender in the overcrowded family of languages trying to be a "Better C++

text: looking up all the alternatives to C/C++ is seriously dizzying. I basically gave up after Rust started to click.

elements.text: looking up all the alternatives to C/C++ is seriously dizzying. I basically gave up after Rust started to click.

text: And I feel like Rust has so much more surface area than Julia.

elements.text: And I feel like Rust has so much more surface area than Julia.

text: References, lifetimes, then macros, borrowchecker, sum types, generics, traits, unsafe rust...

elements.text: References, lifetimes, then macros, borrowchecker, sum types, generics, traits, unsafe rust...

text: I think they compliment each other really really well. Could there be something better than Rust in 5 years? yea. Could there be something better than Julia in 5 years? I honestly don't know...

elements.text: I think they compliment each other really really well. Could there be something better than Rust in 5 years? yea. Could there be something better than Julia in 5 years? I honestly don't know...

text: Julia with the Internals written in Rust :imp:

elements.text: Julia with the Internals written in Rust

text: julia that compiles to Rust!

elements.text: julia that compiles to Rust!

text: Maybe

elements.text: Maybe

text: those PL people have a lot of phd theses to write - it wouldn't be the weirdets combo

elements.text: those PL people have a lot of phd theses to write - it wouldn't be the weirdets combo

text: I'd say Julia isn't really trying to be a better C++ and that's why it actually has a niche to grow from. Like, it's possible we can invade all of C++'s niches with time, but I'd say the language communitity itself has benefited a lot from not trying to be "Like C++ but not bad", and instead just trying to be a good language on it's own terms

elements.text: I'd say Julia isn't really trying to be a better C++ and that's why it actually has a niche to grow from. Like, it's possible we can invade all of C++'s niches with time, but I'd say the language communitity itself has benefited a lot from not trying to be "Like C++ but not bad", and instead just trying to be a good language on it's own terms

text: can you imagine that though... Like using Julia to prototype some really sciencey madness, compiling it, then just dropping it right into Rust with no over head...

elements.text: can you imagine that though... Like using Julia to prototype some really sciencey madness, compiling it, then just dropping it right into Rust with no over head...

text: But you already get taht with type inference  + native code compilation.

elements.text: But you already get taht with type inference  + native code compilation.

text: Yeah, I don't get why we'd want to or need to have anything to do with Rust

elements.text: Yeah, I don't get why we'd want to or need to have anything to do with Rust

text: the overhead is high though and time to first _ is rough for a lot of applications

elements.text: the overhead is high though and time to first _ is rough for a lot of applications

text: Give Jeff and the gang some time - there's still loads of work that can be done.

elements.text: Give Jeff and the gang some time - there's still loads of work that can be done.

text: How would Rust solve that?

elements.text: How would Rust solve that?

text: I mean, people can compile javascript to web assembly so ... give it time.

elements.text: I mean, people can compile javascript to web assembly so ... give it time.

text: oh for sure I'm gonna be sticking with Julia, but for some applications I'm going to try to use Rust. I previously used C++. Rust doesn't solve that, but static Julia would

elements.text: oh for sure I'm gonna be sticking with Julia, but for some applications I'm going to try to use Rust. I previously used C++. Rust doesn't solve that, but static Julia would

text: Agree with Mason - unless you can somehow optimize the type inference algo + compilation pipeline, there's not many other choices.

elements.text: Agree with Mason - unless you can somehow optimize the type inference algo + compilation pipeline, there's not many other choices.

text: multidispatch is just brutal for anything not dynamic. It makes a combinatorial explosion/halting problem

elements.text: multidispatch is just brutal for anything not dynamic. It makes a combinatorial explosion/halting problem

text: Someone's gonna try and make a SMT solver as a backend someday I know it...

elements.text: Someone's gonna try and make a SMT solver as a backend someday I know it...

text: Y'all are forgetting that the language to rule them all is already here: V Lang. It compiles the world in half a second, with no GC to all platforms: your pc, toaster, eraser, fridge and what not. :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:

elements.text: Y'all are forgetting that the language to rule them all is already here: V Lang. It compiles the world in half a second, with no GC to all platforms: your pc, toaster, eraser, fridge and what not.

text: <https://killedbygoogle.com/>
